snippet: While Scots have been warned repeatedly about the dire consequences of voting for independence from the United Kingdom, half — more or less — are expected to do so anyway.
abstract: People of Scotland are set to vote on whether to become independent of Great Britain in a historic referendum; many say yes vote would bring them not only autonomy but also a more Scandinavian-style social democracy--nuclear free and more equitable; opponents warn that Scotland would lose not just the British pound but a sizable chunk of its financial sector as banks and insurers flee south; add that independent Scotland could not afford its current welfare state, let alone expand it, with future of oil revenues uncertain and declining.

byline.original: By STEVEN ERLANGER and KATRIN BENNHOLD
byline.contributor: Steven Erlanger reported from Edinburgh, and Katrin Bennhold from Glasgow.

lead_paragraph: While Scots have been warned repeatedly about the dire consequences of voting for independence from the United Kingdom, half — more or less — are expected to do so anyway.

headline.main: Scottish Vote Weighs Pride Against Risk
headline.print_headline: Scottish Vote Weighs Pride Against Risk
